title: Working with a Tabular Data Resource in R
text: create simple dataset example:
code: d <-   tibble::tibble(     id = c("A01", "A02", "A03"),     date = as.Date(c("2022-07-25", "2018-07-10", "2013-08-15")),     measure = c(12.8, 13.9, 15.6),     rating = factor(c("good", "best", "best"), levels = c("good", "better", "best")),     ranking = as.integer(c(14, 17, 19)),     impt = c(FALSE, TRUE, TRUE)   )

title: Working with a Tabular Data Resource in R
text: creating tabular dataset R, data-specific metadata (.e., ‚Äúdescriptors‚Äù) can stored attributes R object (e.g., data.frame tibble). Note doesn‚Äôt change data values. R, object‚Äôs attributes stored list. attributes (?attributes) treated specially R (e.g., class, names, row.names, comment) usually shouldn‚Äôt modified. Although attributes (including ones added ) available list (?attributes), can use function extract attributes represent metadata descriptors tibble. Similarly, can add column-specific attributes (.e., ‚Äúschema‚Äù). metadata functions follow tidy design principles, making simple expressively concisely add metadata using pipes: Automatically add name, type enum schema column data based class: Like descriptors, helper function retrieve schema tibble. Specify bind = TRUE combine list column-specific attribute data frames column one wider data frame:
code: d <- d |>   add_attrs(     name = "mydata",     title = "My Data",     license = "MIT",     url = "https://geomarker.io/CODECtools"   ) get_descriptors(d) |>   knitr::kable() d <-   d |>   add_col_attrs(id, title = "Identifier", description = "unique identifier") |>   add_col_attrs(date, title = "Date", description = "date of observation") |>   add_col_attrs(measure, title = "Measure", description = "measured quantity") |>   add_col_attrs(rating, title = "Rating", description = "ordered ranking of observation") |>   add_col_attrs(ranking, title = "Ranking", description = "rank of the observation") |>   add_col_attrs(impt, title = "Important", description = "true if this observation is important") d <- add_type_attrs(d) get_schema(d, bind = TRUE) |>   knitr::kable()

title: Working with a Tabular Data Resource in R
text: metadata set tibble‚Äôs attributes, can save tabular data resource CSV file accompanying tabular-data-resource.yaml: name attribute supplied tibble used name newly created folder CSV file containing data. Metadata extracted supplied tibble‚Äôs attributes saved tabular-data-resource.yaml file lives alongside data file newly created directory:
code: write_tdr_csv(d) #> ‚úî created /home/runner/work/CODECtools/CODECtools/vignettes/mydata/ #> ‚úî wrote data to /home/runner/work/CODECtools/CODECtools/vignettes/mydata/mydata.csv #> ‚úî wrote metadata to /home/runner/work/CODECtools/CODECtools/vignettes/mydata/tabular-data-resource.yaml fs::dir_tree("mydata") #> mydata #> ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ mydata.csv #> ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ tabular-data-resource.yaml

title: Working with a Tabular Data Resource in R
text: can read tabular-data-package back R restore attributes, well column classes:
code: mydata <- read_tdr_csv("mydata") #> ‚úî read in data from mydata/mydata.csv #> Warning: Outer names are only allowed for unnamed scalar atomic inputs mydata #> # A tibble: 3 √ó 7 #>   id    date       measure rating ranking impt  field #>   <chr> <date>       <dbl> <fct>    <int> <lgl> <chr> #> 1 A01   2022-07-25    12.8 good        14 FALSE A01   #> 2 A02   2018-07-10    13.9 best        17 TRUE  A02   #> 3 A03   2013-08-15    15.6 best        19 TRUE  A03

title: NA
text: data often comes different spatiotemporal resolutions extents; often also private, individual-level data interested neighborhood-level numbers pro: solves privacy-related issues allowing contribution aggregate data without disclosing individual-level data pro: modularize make several flexible options types/source/methods data input con: direct link source data aggregate outputs; verify processes data source use individual-level data

title: NA
text: set patterns describing data, including datasets (Data Package), files (Data Resource), tables (Table Schema) Data Package simple container format used describe package collection data metadata, including schemas Table Schema: describes tabular file providing dimension, field data types, relations, constraints Data Resource: describes exact tabular file providing path file details like title, description, others Tabular Data Resource = Data Resource + Table Schema Data Package & Tabular Data Package: describes collection tabular files providing data resource information along general information package , license, authors, metadata Data Package Identifier (supports URL file & folder, github url; use argument specifying data) CSV dialect

title: NA
text: üîé findable: use unique persistent identifier, add rich metadata (usingexisting standards) üîì accessible: store data repository ( ‚ö†Ô∏è personal/classified information, metadata still accessible) ‚öôÔ∏è interoperable: use open file format controlled vocabularies, reference relevant datasets ‚ôªÔ∏è reusable: good documentation including README (project background, organization files, reproduce project) data dictionary (variable explainations, measurement units, missingness encoded, etc); usage licenses (code data/presentations/papers

what: 1. add metadata using attributes inside R
title: NA
text: Inside R, frictionless metadata lives attributes data.frame columns. can add change several helper functions: add table-level metadata using set_attrs() add schema (column-level) metadata using set_col_attrs() use internal R tools adjust classes factor levels use add_type_attrs() class info ‚Äútype‚Äù attributes (correspond Frictionless schema specifications) Using functions set attributes R means can reproducibly changes metadata tracked alongside R script creates data. Alternatively, can edit metadata yaml file directly track changes . Reading data back R using function also reads metadata update attributes data.frame based changes metadata file. Note: automagic behavior setting attributes column classes data.frame R based metadata file supported filetypes CSV (e.g., parquet, feather, RDS, gpkg, qs, fst) filtypes inherent schema metadata built ensure R reads data correct format. using non-CSV file, metadata attributes R always derived data file , rather metadata file. case, dataset-level metadata, source URL, author, vintage, file format, others can still included accompanying metadata file. ideal Frictionless data package uses non-CSV file (e.g., parquet) matching schema data object metadata document.

text: goal CODECtools support CODEC data infrastructure : capturing, creating, accessing metadata tabular data R importing exporting tabular data resources (CSV file) metadata (YAML file) defining CODEC data format specifications (vignette package) providing tools workflows validate CODEC data contribute CODECdata repository creation online data catalog

what: get CODEC descriptors and schema ‚Äî get_descriptors
title: get CODEC descriptors and schema ‚Äî get_descriptors
text: functions designed provide simple way extract tibbles descriptors schema data frames columns attributes: get_descriptors() gets descriptors data frame get_col_descriptors() gets field-specific descriptors single column inside data frame get_schema() gets field-specific descriptors columns inside data frame

title: get CODEC descriptors and schema ‚Äî get_descriptors
code: get_descriptors(.x, codec = TRUE)  get_col_descriptors(.x, codec = TRUE)  get_schema(.x, bind = TRUE, codec = TRUE)

what: read a CSV tabular data resource into R ‚Äî read_tdr_csv
title: read a CSV tabular data resource into R ‚Äî read_tdr_csv
text: CSV file defined tabular-data-resource yaml file read R using readr::read_csv(). Metadata (descriptors schema) stored attributes returned tibble also used set column classes returned data.frame tibble.

title: Tidy eval helpers ‚Äî tidyeval
text: page lists tidy eval tools reexported package rlang. learn using tidy eval scripts packages high level, see dplyr programming vignette ggplot2 packages vignette. Metaprogramming section Advanced R may also useful deeper dive. tidy eval operators {{, !!, !!! syntactic constructs specially interpreted tidy eval functions. mostly need {{, !! !!! advanced operators use simple cases. curly-curly operator {{ allows tunnel data-variables passed function arguments inside tidy eval functions. {{ designed individual arguments. pass multiple arguments contained dots, use ... normal way.   enquo() enquos() delay execution one several function arguments. former returns single expression, latter returns list expressions. defused, expressions longer evaluate . must injected back evaluation context !! (single expression) !!! (list expressions).   simple case, code equivalent usage {{ ... . Defusing enquo() enquos() needed complex cases, instance need inspect modify expressions way. .data pronoun object represents current slice data. variable name string, use .data pronoun subset variable [[.   Another tidy eval operator :=. makes possible use glue curly-curly syntax LHS =. technical reasons, R language support complex expressions left =, use := workaround.   Many tidy eval functions like dplyr::mutate() dplyr::summarise() give automatic name unnamed inputs. need create sort automatic names , use as_label(). instance, glue-tunnelling syntax can reproduced manually :   Expressions defused enquo() (tunnelled {{) need simple column names, can arbitrarily complex. as_label() handles cases gracefully. code assumes simple column name, use as_name() instead. safer throws error input name expected.
code: my_function <- function(data, var, ...) {   data %>%     group_by(...) %>%     summarise(mean = mean({{ var }})) } my_function <- function(data, var, ...) {   # Defuse   var <- enquo(var)   dots <- enquos(...)    # Inject   data %>%     group_by(!!!dots) %>%     summarise(mean = mean(!!var)) } my_var <- "disp" mtcars %>% summarise(mean = mean(.data[[my_var]])) my_function <- function(data, var, suffix = "foo") {   # Use `{{` to tunnel function arguments and the usual glue   # operator `{` to interpolate plain strings.   data %>%     summarise("{{ var }}_mean_{suffix}" := mean({{ var }})) } my_function <- function(data, var, suffix = "foo") {   var <- enquo(var)   prefix <- as_label(var)   data %>%     summarise("{prefix}_mean_{suffix}" := mean(!!var)) }

title: extract data resource metadata from a data frame and save it to a file ‚Äî write_tdr
code: if (FALSE) { mtcars |>   add_attrs(name = "Motor Trend Cars", year = "1974") |>   add_col_attrs(mpg, title = "MPG", description = "Miles Per Gallon") |>   add_type_attrs() |>   save_tdr(my_mtcars, "my_mtcars_tabular-data-resource.yaml") }

what: write a tabular-data-resource yaml file and data csv file based on a data.frame or tibble ‚Äî write_tdr_csv
title: write a tabular-data-resource yaml file and data csv file based on a data.frame or tibble ‚Äî write_tdr_csv
text: path argument specifies folder containing codec-tdr created.  Within path, folder codec-tdr named based name attribute data.frame tibble. CSV data file named based name attribute data.frame tibble "tabular-data-resource.yaml" file also created.

title: write a tabular-data-resource yaml file and data csv file based on a data.frame or tibble ‚Äî write_tdr_csv
